values: "Everlasting uncertainty and agitation distinguish the bourgeois epoch from all earlier ones. All fixed, fast-frozen relations . . . are swept away, all new-formed ones become antiquated before they can ossify. All that is solid melts into air."

sometimes we get overzealous in our spring cleaning, and we throw out a bunch of old shit we'll eventually miss. other times, we misplace a bunch of shit that means a lot to us and we can never find it again. sometimes it's hard to tell whether you lost your shit or whether your shit lost you, and sometimes you can't tell if that shit even belonged to you in the first place. 
i guess, in the end, we need to look at things for what they are: gone, and shit.

-When studying personality types and their impact on policy, scholars examine a leader's basic orientations toward self and toward others, behavioral patterns, and attitudes towards about such politically relevant concepts as authority. There are numerous categorization schemes. The most well known of these places political personality along an active-passive scale and a positive-negative scale. Active leaders are policy innovators; passive leaders are reactors. Positive personalities have egos strong enough to enjoy (or at least accept) the contentious political environment; negative personalities are apt to feel burdened, even abused by political criticism. Many scholars favor active-positive presidents, but all four types have drawbacks. Activists, for example, may feel compelled to solve every problem even though not doing anything might be preferable. That was true in some cases for President Clinton, whom most political psychology studies categorized as an extremely activist personality, and who himself admitted to being "almost compulsively overactive."-

-Whatever the best combination may be, there is wider agreement that the worst is active-negative. The more active a leader, the more criticism he or she encounters. Rather than taking criticism in stride, though, the leader assumes that opponents are enemies and may withdraw into an inner circle of subordinates who are supportive and give an unreal view of events and domestic and international opinion. Adolf Hitler and Josef Stalin and, to a lesser degree, Lyndon Johnson and Richard Nixon were all active-negative personalities who showed symptoms of delusion, struck out at their enemies, and generally developed bunker mentalities.-

It's a little sad when political scholars use political criminals to illustrate the particular political personality type you possess. I'm going to go build my bunker.

i sit in a public city school. underfunded.
the teacher lies. the boy behind me kicks the wall.
the bricks crumble to reveal dirty dishes on the other side.
the wall was only an inch think. the bricks were painted plywood.
the girl throws a chair at the black board and slams herself against the window.
the teacher covers her ears and screams.

the three children and i morph into older versions of ourselves.
we stand under a bridge and stare at a red wooden door cut into the stone.
the paint on the door is chipped.
we know what's on the other side, and we know we need to kill it.
we shoot at the door and it crumbles, revealing another red door, with bullet holes. they bleed.
we shoot the door and open the black door behind it. we cock our pistols and enter.

we exit, and i'm thanked for my accuracy. i unload my pistol at the screen triumphantly.

he walks me down the storefront street, his luger pointed at my forehead. i'm indifferent.
with unsteady steps i walk backwards. people barely notice what's happening.
my clothes are tattered and caked with dried blood.
he wears the blue, red, and white uniform of a colonial soldier circa 1776.
he asks me if i have the strength to lie on the curb up across the street.
i calmy comply and he empties his chamber.

i stand over my body, holding the gun.
i look around to find only two other people on the street.
they act indifferent to what they see.
i toss the gun down onto my body, but leave my white gloves on.
they are freckled with red.
i walk down the street, and begin to enter the coffee house so i can phone 911.
i see the man who had been walking down the street begin to run to the pay phone next to my body.
he's going to call the police and tell them i killed myself. i run after him.
he sees me running and runs a few yards away from the phone.
i pick up the dangling phone and all i hear is a constant dial tone. uninterrupted, nothing happens when i press the buttons or the lever.
i scream and my face turns scarlet. my lungs throb and my voice cracks. tears stream down my face, and...

the phone next to my pillow rings and awakens me. i pick it up and the person on the other line sounds confused. they have an accent and i hang up the phone. i turn it off.

aw, my baby used bourgeois as an insult today for the very first time. i feel warm and tingly.

Today has been shitty from the get-go, and i feel fantabular.

first, my dad woke me up at 7:00 to ask me what time i needed to be at work. 
um, now. she-it.
so i called seamus and everything was fine. it turns out he was an hour late too.
then i picked up bagels, and let me tell you, pulling a left turn onto rt.202 from the country deli at rush hour is some scary squirrely shit.
so, a few hours later i was making a bagel for this cute little munchkin, and i accidentally sliced my ring finger in half. i cleaned the knife off, and then got james to make the bagel since i was all monty python, and everything was ok again. 
james told me to sit down at the desk in the back and keep my hand elevated, and he went out to help more customers.
a felt a little woozy, but then i was listening to the music (i am the egg man) and i felt better. 
the next thing i know, i'm laying on the floor, at the foot of the desk, and james is asking me if i'm all right. i tell him i'm great, and he leaves. i look at my foot, which is the only thing left on the chair, and i think that it was a great idea to raise my feet, since this prevents fainting.. 
finally, after i stare at the file cabinet an inch from my head on the right, and the dustballs under the desk on left do i realize that yes, i've fainted. after a few giggles i get up and wipe the blood that's collected on the floor during my departure and i realize i feel like i'm on cloud 9. fainting is mucho underrated. laura came in a minute later and gave me a drop of this liquor stuff and she put neosporin on my finger. 
a few other icky things happened, like getting two parking tickets from those skanky po-lice and talking to a really sad little one who wanted her mum on the phone. 

i left an hour later, and the only negative thing i can think of is my head and neck hurting pretty bad. (i can't feel the appendage) 
the weird thing is: i haven't felt this good in weeks.

immobilized, i
can't remember the last time
i gave an honest laugh or handshake
or wept with tears that weren't delayed by days or years
i dry heave, coughing alone in my room
i curl and shake and hope that some release will come sometime soon
i'm always hoping
always waiting to escape, i'm forever plotting exits 
if i belong anywhere, it's clearly anywhere but here
i'm always missing blurred faces and unfamiliar places
everything i've remotely loved i've remotely grown to fear
i have no great shame, nor remorse, or regret
no great truths, nor discoveries, or dark secrets
i'm more complex than i could ever casually admit
more simple than my pride could comfortably permit
of all the things tinged with familiarity
loss is surely at the top of that list

i want you to grab a mirror.
go, grab it.
ok, now gaze into the truth. a little vanity ain't hurt no one.
now: 
do you know that divot, between your upper lip and your nose?
is it big?
bigger than most divots?
if it is, i have some truth for you, and yes, it can be taken for gospel. 
you are a heinous, self absorbed, pretentious individual who thrives on social darwinism.
your style's far from fresh, and when you try to look sultry, you look like a monkey.

that is all.

i saw three beautiful people last week.

no more, and no less.

e'hm.

the first person i saw was at westchester. 
i was walking along a path, and he was approaching me on my right.
he was probably the blackest black i've ever seen (most likely an african exchange student), and his eyes and teeth were pure white. i've never seen anyone so human and yet so ethereal at the same time. there is beauty in black.

the second person i saw was a woman i helped at work. 
she was old, maybe 70.
her skin was like soft crinkled paper and her eyes were muted.  
it's interesting how the beauty of young girls and women is often noted but the beauty of the elderly is overlooked. she was beautiful. like the boy, there was nothing attractive about her usual features, but something captivating about her skin, eyes, and teeth.

the third person i saw was a young girl standing on the side walk of a rundown area in peekskill. i caught a glimpse of her as i was driving by.
she was probably 6 or 7 years old.
she stood, with both hands holding a gallon jug of orange juice over her head, drinking in a way that reminded me of how a warrior would hold the heart of an enemy or prize catch above his head, triumphantly sinking his teeth into the flesh. it was glorious and modern and telling.

 bastardos.

 i wrestled ourselves to bruises, gouges, and exhaustion.

I HEAR it was charged against me that I sought to destroy
     institutions,
But really I am neither for nor against institutions,
(What indeed have I in common with them? or what with 
     the destruction of them?)
Only I will establish in the Mannahatta and in every city of
     these states inland and seaboard,
And in the fields and woods, and above every keel little or
     large that dents the water,
Without edifices or rules or trustees or any argument,
The institution of the dear love of comrades.
                                    -Walt Whitman

enlightened, the creature, it must surely know
this fetus will die here, desperate, willing, and alone.
